facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 231 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 231 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 11, 1953, of the Rajasthan High Court Jaipur Bench at Jaipur in Writ Application No. 141 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 11, 1953, of the Rajasthan High Court  Jaipur Bench  at Jaipur in Writ Application No. 141 of 1952.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on August 18, 1960 by RAJAGOPALA AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. August 18. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAJAGOPALA AYYANGAR, J.-This appeal raises for companysideration the companystitutional validity of one paragraph of a numberification issued by the State of Rajasthan under s. 15 of the Police Act, 1861  V of 1861 , under which the Harijan and Muslim inhabitants of the villages, in which an additional police force was stationed, were exempted from the obligation to bear any portion of the companyt of that force.

facts.text: Inhabitants of certain villages in the district of Jhunjhunu in the State of Rajasthan harboured dacoits and receivers of stolen property.

anchor.surface_text: It is stated that the inhabitants of certain villages in the district of Jhunjhunu in the State of Rajasthan, harboured dacoits and receivers of stolen property, and were besides creating trouble between landlords and tenants as a result of which there were serious riots in the locality in the course of which some persons lost their lives.

facts.text: Inhabitants of certain villages in Jhunjhunu created trouble between landlords and tenants resulting in serious riots in which some persons lost their lives.

anchor.surface_text: It is stated that the inhabitants of certain villages in the district of Jhunjhunu in the State of Rajasthan, harboured dacoits and receivers of stolen property, and were besides creating trouble between landlords and tenants as a result of which there were serious riots in the locality in the course of which some persons lost their lives.

facts.text: State Government took action under s. 15 of the Police Act, 1861.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government therefore took action under s. 15 of the Police Act.

facts.text: Rajpramukh issued notification declaring 24 villages in schedule as disturbed area for six months from date of notification.

anchor.surface_text: Whereas the Rajpramukh is satisfied that the area shown in the schedule annexed hereto has been found to be in a disturbed and dangerous state Now, therefore, in the exercise of the authority vested in him under Section 15 1  of the Police Act  V of 1861 , the Rajpramukh is pleased to declare that the 24 villages included in the said schedule shall be deemed to be disturbed area for a period of six months from the date of this numberification.

facts.text: Rajpramukh authorised Inspector-General of Police to employ additional police force at cost of inhabitants of the 24 villages.

anchor.surface_text: Under sub-section 2 of the said section 15 of the Police Act  V of 1861 , the Rajpramukh is pleased to authorise the Inspector-General of Police to employ, at the companyt of the inhabitants of the said area any Police force in addition to the ordinary fixed companyplement quartered therein.

facts.text: Notification exempted Harijan and Muslim inhabitants of the 24 villages from liability to bear any portion of the cost of additional police force.

anchor.surface_text: Under sub-section 5 of section 15 of the said Act the Rajpramukh is further pleased to exempt the Harijan and Muslim inhabitants of these villages from liability to bear any portion of the companyt on account of the posting of the additional Police force.

facts.text: Thakur Pratap Singh is inhabitant of Baragaon, one of the 24 villages.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-Thakur Pratap Singh being an inhabitant of Baragaon-one of these 24 villages, moved the High Court of Rajasthan for the issue of a writ or direction under Act. 226 of the Constitution impugning the validity of s. 15 of the Police Act and in particular of sub-s. 5 thereof and of the numberification and praying for appropriate reliefs.

facts.text: Thakur Pratap Singh filed writ petition in Rajasthan High Court under Article 226 impugning validity of s.15 Police Act, particularly sub-s.5, and the notification.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-Thakur Pratap Singh being an inhabitant of Baragaon-one of these 24 villages, moved the High Court of Rajasthan for the issue of a writ or direction under Act. 226 of the Constitution impugning the validity of s. 15 of the Police Act and in particular of sub-s. 5 thereof and of the numberification and praying for appropriate reliefs.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court held that para 4 of the notification exempting Harijan and Muslim inhabitants is violative of Article 15(1) and struck it down.

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judges hold that Para 4 of the numberification which exempted Harijan and Muslim inhabitants of the villages from the levy, was violative of the guarantee in Art. 15 1  of the Constitution against discrimination on the ground of caste or religion etc. ... and struck it down as unconstitutional.

facts.text: High Court repelled contentions regarding invalidity of s.15 Police Act in general and powers to exempt under sub-s.5.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled the wider contentions urged regarding the invalidity of s. 15 of the Police Act in general as also of the powers conferred on the State Government to order the exemption of any person or classes or sections of such inhabitants from liability to bear the cost of the additional police force.

facts.text: State of Rajasthan applied to High Court for certificate under Article 132(1), which was granted.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Rajasthan who felt aggrieved by this order applied to the High Court for a certificate under Art. 132 1  to enable it to file an appeal to this court and this having been granted, the appeal is now before us.

facts.text: In para 5 of the writ petition, respondent averred that notification discriminates on basis of religion, race or caste, contravening Article 15.

anchor.surface_text: In para 5 f  of the petition filed before the High Court the respondent had averred That the aforesaid Notification is ultra vires of the Constitution of India as it discriminates amongst the Citizens of a village on the basis of religion, race or caste, in as much as it makes a distinction between persons professing the Mohammadan religion and others and also between persons who are Muslims and Harijans by caste and the rest. It, therefore contravenes the provisions of Article 15 of the Constitution of India.

facts.text: State contended that Harijan and Muslim inhabitants exempted because they were peace-loving and law-abiding citizens, not because of religion, race or caste.

anchor.surface_text: The answer to this by the State was in these terms The Harijan and Muslim inhabitants of these villages have been exempted from liability to bear any portion of the cost of the additional force not because of their religion, race or caste but because they were found to be peace-loving and law-abiding citizens, in the 24 villages additional force has been posted.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that exemption in para 4 of notification is contrary to Article 15(1).

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that the numberification is directly contrary to the terms of Art. 15 1  and that para 4 of the numberification has incurred condemnation as violating a specific constitutional prohibition.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the learned Judges of the High Court were clearly right in striking down this paragraph of the numberification. The appeal fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: It was not contended by the State that there were no peaceful and law-abiding persons in the 24 villages belonging to other communities.

anchor.surface_text: Even if it be that the bulk of the members of the communities exempted or even all of them were law-abiding, it was not contended on behalf of the State that there were no peaceful and law-abiding persons in these 24 villages belonging to the other communities on whom the punitive levy had been directed to be made.

facts.text: Counsel for appellants: S. K. Sastri and T. M. Sen. Respondent did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: S. K. Sastri and T. M. Sen, for the appellants. The respondent did number appear.
under s. 15 of the Police Act, 1861  V of 1861 , under which the Harijan and Muslim inhabitants of the villages, in which an additional police force was stationed, were exempted

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to quarter additional police in disturbed areas and apportion cost to inhabitants, with exemption power

anchor.surface_text: This Section provides Quartering of additional police in disturbed or dangerous districts- It shall be lawful for the State Government, by proclamation to be numberified in the official Gazette, and in such other manner as the State Government shall direct, to declare that any area subject to its authority has been found to be in a disturbed or dangerous state, or that, from the companyduct of the inhabitants of such area, or of any class or section of them, it is expedient to increase the number of police.

issues.text: constitutional validity of one paragraph of a notification issued by the State of Rajasthan under s. 15 of the Police Act, 1861 under which the Harijan and Muslim inhabitants of the villages, in which an additional police force was stationed, were exempted from the obligation to bear any portion of the cost of that force

anchor.surface_text: This appeal raises for consideration the constitutional validity of one paragraph of a notification issued by the State of Rajasthan under s. 15 of the Police Act, 1861 V of 1861 , under which the Harijan and Muslim inhabitants of the villages, in which an additional police force was stationed, were exempted

issues.text: validity of s. 15 of the Police Act

issues.text: validity of sub-s. 5 of s. 15 of the Police Act

anchor.surface_text: impugning the validity of s. 15 of the Police Act and in particular of sub-s. 5 thereof and of the notification and praying for appropriate reliefs.

issues.text: whether Para 4 of the notification which exempted Harijan and Muslim inhabitants of the villages from the levy, was violative of the guarantee in Art. 15(1) of the Constitution against discrimination on the ground of caste or religion

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judges hold that Para 4 of the notification which exempted Harijan and Muslim inhabitants of the villages from the levy, was violative of the guarantee in Art. 15 1  of the Constitution against discrimination on the ground of caste or religion etc.

issues.text: whether the exemption of the Harijan Muslim inhabitants of the villages, was, in the impugned notification, not based only on the ground of caste or religion or the other criteria set out in Art. 15(1), but on the ground that persons belonging to these two communities were found by the State to have been guilty of the conduct which necessitated the stationing of the additional police force

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the State made a strenuous effort to show that the exemption of the Harijan Muslim inhabitants of the villages, was, in the impugned notification, number based only on the ground of caste or religion or the other criteria set out in Art. 15 1 , but on the ground that persons belonging to these two communities were found by the State number to have been guilty of the conduct

anchor.surface_text: the aforesaid Notification is ultra vires of the Constitution of India as it discriminates amongst the Citizens of a village on the basis of religion, race or caste... It, therefore contravenes the provisions of Article 15 of the Constitution of India.

arguments.claim: The notification is ultra vires as it discriminates on the basis of religion, race or caste between Muslims/Harijans and others, contravening Article 15.

anchor.surface_text: That the aforesaid Notification is ultra vires of the Constitution of India as it discriminates amongst the Citizens of a village on the basis of religion, race or caste, in as much as it makes a distinction between persons professing the Mohammadan religion and others and also between persons who are Muslims and Harijans by caste and the rest. It, therefore contravenes the provisions of Article 15 of the Constitution of India.

arguments.claim: Para 4 of the notification exempting Harijan and Muslim inhabitants is violative of Art. 15(1) against discrimination on ground of caste or religion.

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judges hold that Para 4 of the numberification which exempted Harijan and Muslim inhabitants of the villages from the levy, was violative of the guarantee in Art. 15 1  of the Constitution against discrimination on the ground of caste or religion etc. ... and struck it down as unconstitutional.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: essing the Mohammadan religion and others and also between persons who are Muslims and Harijans by caste and the rest. It, therefore, companytravenes

arguments.court_reasoning: Plainly contrary to Art. 15(1); High Court clearly right.

arguments.claim: Notification discriminated against law-abiding members of other communities in favour of Harijan/Muslim on basis only of caste or religion.

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that the numberification has discriminated against the law-abiding members of the other communities and in favour of the Muslim and Harijan communities, assuming that every one of them was peace-loving and law-abiding on the basis only of caste or religion .

arguments.claim: If there were other grounds for exemption beyond caste/religion, they ought to have been stated in the notification.

anchor.surface_text: If there were other grounds they ought to have been stated in the numberification.

arguments.claim: The exemption argument that only certain communities are law-abiding is strange, as disturbing elements exist in any community.

anchor.surface_text: Now this is a very strange argument that only persons of a certain community or caste were law-abiding citizens, while the members of other communities were not. Disturbing elements may be found among members of any community or religion just as much as there may be saner elements among members of that community or religion.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: granted, the appeal is number before us. Learned Counsel for the State made a strenuous effort to s

holdings.text: Paragraph 4 of the notification, exempting Harijan and Muslim inhabitants, violates Article 15(1) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is plain that the numberification is directly companytrary to the terms of Art. 15 1  and that para 4 of the numberification has incurred companydemnation as violating a specific companystitu- tional prohibition.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The exemption discriminates solely on grounds of caste and religion without stating other grounds, violating the prohibition in Art. 15(1); even assuming exempted communities law-abiding, it burdens law-abiding others on prohibited grounds.

holdings.text: The High Court's rejection of the State's argument that exemption was based on conduct rather than caste or religion is correct.

anchor.surface_text: The view here expressed by the learned Judges is, in our opinion, companyrect. Even if it be that the bulk of the members of the companymunities exempted or even all of them were law-abiding,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Argument implies only certain communities are law-abiding, which is untenable as disturbing elements exist in all communities; not contended that no law-abiding persons existed in other communities.

holdings.text: The notification discriminates against law-abiding members of other communities on the basis only of caste or religion.

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows that the numberification has discriminated against the law-abiding members of the other companymunities and in favour of the Muslim and Harijan companymunities,  assuming that every one of them was peace-loving and law-abiding  on the basis only of caste or religion .

holdings.reasoning_summary: State's reply admits possibility of law-abiding in other communities; exemption thus favors one group over another solely on caste/religion.

holdings.text: If grounds for exemption other than caste or religion existed, they ought to have been stated in the notification.

anchor.surface_text: If there were other grounds they ought to have been stated in the numberification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of stated non-prohibited grounds confirms violation of Art. 15(1).

holdings.text: The High Court was right in striking down paragraph 4 of the notification; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the learned Judges of the High Court were clearly right in striking down this paragraph of the numberification. The appeal fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirms violation of Art. 15(1) as directly contrary to constitutional prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: The appeal fails and is dismissed

edges.explanation: The issue explicitly describes the constitutional validity of a notification issued under s. 15 of the Police Act, 1861, directly referencing the concept in c1.
The issue concerns the constitutional validity of a notification under Section 15, Police Act 1861, which c2 instantiates.
The issue concerns a notification under Section 15, and c4 refers to the specific subsection 15(1).
The issue concerns a notification under Section 15, and c5 refers to the specific subsection 15(2).
Resolving the constitutional validity issue requires a holding on whether the specific exemption in the notification violates Article 15(1).
